article.title: Copenhagen

template.arg: From upper left: [[Christiansborg Palace]], [[Frederik's Church]], [[Tivoli Gardens]] and [[Nyhavn]].
Greater coat of arms of Copenhagen.svg

article.paragraph: Copenhagen(IPAc-enIPAˌkoʊpənˈheɪɡən;cite webCopenhagen I Define Copenhaguen at Dictionary.comhttp://dictionary.reference.com/browse/copenhagendictionary.comRandom House Inc.11 May 2015lang-daKøbenhavnIPA-dakʰøb̥m̩ˈhɑʊ̯ˀn(Audioda-København.ogglistenno)) is the capital and most populated city ofDenmark, with anUrban areaurbanpopulation of 1,263,698 (As of20150101on) and aMetropolitan areametropolitanpopulation of 1,992,114 (As of20150101on). It is situated on the eastern coast ofZealand,convert164kmoneast ofOdenseandconvert28kmonnorthwest ofMalm, Sweden. The city stretches across parts of the island ofAmagerand contains the enclave ofFrederiksberg, a municipality in its own right.

Founded as a fishing village in the 10th century,Denmark-Norwaydeveloped the village Copenhagen into the capital of the state in the early 15th century. Beginning in the 17th century, under the reign ofChristian IV of DenmarkChristian IVof theGermanyGermanHouse of Oldenburg, Copenhagen developed into an importantEuropeanregional centre, consolidating its position as capital of Denmark and Norway with resources from both kingdoms being used to build institutions, even palaces and the famous fortifications which shapes the city still. Magnificent architectural expressions of prestige in Denmark-Norway include some of Copenhagens most important tourist attractions, such as TheBrsen(The Exchange), TheRundetrn(Round Tower),Rosenborg Castleand more recentlyFrederiksstaden. After suffering from the effects ofGreat Northern War plague outbreakplagueand fire in the 18th century, the city underwent a period of redevelopment. This included construction of the prestigious district ofFrederiksstadenand founding of such cultural institutions as theRoyal Danish TheatreRoyal Theatreand theRoyal Danish Academy of Fine ArtsRoyal Academy of Fine Arts. After further disasters in the early 19th century whenHoratio NelsonNelsonattacked the Dano-Norwegian fleet and bombarded the city, rebuilding during theDanish Golden Agebrought aNeoclassical architectureNeoclassicallook to Copenhagen's architecture. Later, following theSecond World War, theFinger Planfostered the development of housing and businesses along the five urban railway routes stretching out from the city centre.

Since the turn of the 21st century, Copenhagen has seen strong urban and cultural development, facilitated by investment in its institutions and infrastructure. The city is theCulture of Denmarkcultural,Economy of DenmarkeconomicandPolitics of Denmarkgovernmentalcentre of Denmark; it is one of the major financial centres of Northern Europe with theCopenhagen Stock Exchange. Since the completion of theresund Bridge, a road, railway and tunnel project, theCopenhagen metropolitan areahas become increasingly integrated with the Swedish province ofScaniaand its largest city, Malm, known as theresund Region. With a number of bridges connecting the various districts, the cityscape is characterized by parks, promenades and waterfronts. Copenhagen's landmarks such asTivoli Gardens, theThe Little Mermaid (statue)Little Mermaid Statue, theAmalienborgandChristiansborg PalaceChristiansborgpalaces,Rosenborg Castle,Frederik's Church, and many museums, restaurants and nightclubs are significant tourist attractions. In addition to recent developments in the cityservice sectorand thepharmaceuticalindustry, there have been a number of initiatives inclean technology, supporting the city's goal to becarbon-neutralby 2025.

Copenhagen has more than 94,000 students enrolled in its largest universities and institutions, including theUniversity of Copenhagen, theTechnical University of DenmarkandCopenhagen Business School. The University of Copenhagen, founded in1479, is the oldest university in Denmark. Copenhagen is home to theF.C. CopenhagenFC KbenhavnandBrndby IFBrndbyfootball clubs and the ice hockey teamsRdovre Mighty Bulls,Herlev HornetsHerlev EaglesandHvidovre Ligahockey. The annualCopenhagen Marathonwas established in 1980. Copenhagen is one of the most bicycle-friendly cities in the world. TheCopenhagen Metroserves central Copenhagen together with theS-trainnetwork connecting the outlying boroughs. Serving roughly 2 million passengers a month,Copenhagen AirportCopenhagen Airport, Kastrup, is the largest airport in theNordic countries.
article.heading: Etymology
article.paragraph: The name of the city reflects its origin as a harbour and a place of commerce. The original designation, from which the contemporary Danish name derives, wasKpmannhafn, meaning "merchants' harbour", often simplyHafnorHavn("harbour"). The Englishcognatewould be "ChapmenChapman'sHarborhaven".cite webhttp://www.eremit.dk/ebog/khb/1/khb1_2.htmlOluf NielsenKjøbenhavn i MiddelalderenG.E.C. Gad187723 November 2013DanishThe English name for the city was adapted from itsLow Germanname,Kopenhagen. The abbreviationsKbh.orKbhvnare often used in Danish forKbenhavn, andkbh.forkbenhavnsk(of Copenhagen).ABBREVIATIONS AND ACRONYMS USED IN THE PRESS OF DENMARK, glossary by Foreign Broadcast Information Service, Washington DC, USA

The city'sLatinname isHafnia. The chemical elementhafniumis named for Copenhagen, where it was discovered.cite bookAndré AuthierEarly Days of X-ray Crystallographyhttps://books.google.com/books?id1 August 2013OUP Oxford978-0-19-163501-4153sfnCardarelli2008336The bacteriumHafnia (bacterium)Hafniais also named after Copenhagen: Vagn Mller of theState Serum Institutein Copenhagen named it in 1954.cite webhttp://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1360275/ The Genus Hafnia: from Soup to Nuts US National Library of Medicine National Institutes of Health30 January 20139 March 2013
article.heading: History
Early history
article.paragraph: Although the earliest historical records of Copenhagen are from the end of the12th century, recentarchaeologicalfinds in connection with work on the city's metropolitan rail system revealed the remains of a large merchant's mansion near today'sKongens Nytorvfrom c.1020. Excavations inPilestrdehave also led to the discovery of a well from the late 12th century. The remains of an ancient church, with graves dating to the11th century, have been unearthed near whereStrgetmeetsRdhuspladsen.

These finds indicate that Copenhagen's origins as a city go back at least to the11th century. Substantial discoveries offlinttools in the area provide evidence of human settlements dating to theStone Age.cite webhttp://videnskab.dk/kultur-samfund/arkaeologer-graver-ny-teori-om-kobenhavn-op-af-muldenArkæologer graver ny teori om København op af mulden''Videnskab.dk''5 November 200812 November 2013DanishMany historians believe the town dates to the lateViking Age, and was possibly founded bySweyn ForkbeardSweyn I Forkbeard.sfnCunningham201335The natural harbour and goodherringstocks seem to have attracted fishermen and merchants to the area on a seasonal basis from the11th centuryand more permanently in the13th century.cite webhttp://www.denstoredanske.dk/Danmarks_geografi_og_historie/Danmarks_geografi/K%c3%b8benhavn/K%c3%b8benhavn/K%c3%b8benhavn_-_historieKøbenhavn - historie''Den Store Danske''12 November 2013DanishThe first habitations were probably centred onGammel Strand(literally "old shore") in the 11th century or even earlier.cite webhttp://www.copenhagen.dk/dk/kulturmiljo/historier_om_kbenhavn/gammel_strand1/Gammel StrandKøbenhavns Museum24 November 2013Danish

The earliest written mention of the town was in the 12th century whenSaxo GrammaticusinGesta Danorumreferred to it asPortus Mercatorum, meaning Merchants' Harbour or, in theDanish languageDanishof the time,Kbmannahavn.Skaarup; Jensen (2002), pp. 1415Traditionally, Copenhagen's founding has been dated toAbsalonBishop Absalon's construction of a modest fortress on the little island ofSlotsholmenin1167whereChristiansborg Palacestands today.sfnDavies1944365The construction of the fortress was in response to attacks byWendsWendishpirates who plagued the coastline during the 12th century.sfnHarding200938Defensive ramparts and moats were completed and by 1177 St. Clemens Church had been built. Attacks by the Germans continued, and after the original fortress was eventually destroyed by the marauders, islanders replaced it withCopenhagen Castle.SfnChristopher200678
article.heading: Middle Ages
article.paragraph: File:Arsenal Museum Copenhagen backend.jpgthumbTheTjhus MuseumTjhus Arsenal(1604)File:Old Stock Exchange Copenhagen, pic-001.JPGthumbTheBrsen, former stock exchange (completed1640)In 1186, a letter fromPope Urban IIIstates that the castle ofHafn(Copenhagen) and its surrounding lands, including the town of Hafn, were given to Absalon, Bishop of Roskilde 1158-1191 and Archbishop of Lund 1177-1201, by KingValdemar I of DenmarkValdemar I. On Absalon's death, the property was to come into the ownership of theDiocese of Roskilde (Roman-Catholic)Bishopric of Roskilde.Around 1200, theChurch of Our Lady (Copenhagen)Church of Our Ladywas constructed on higher ground to the northeast of the town, which began to develop around it.

As the town became more prominent, it was repeatedly attacked by theHanseatic League. As the fishing industry thrived in Copenhagen, particularly in the trade ofherring, the city began expanding to the north of Slotsholmen.sfnHarding200938In 1254, it received a charter as a city under BishopJakob Erlandsencite bookCopenhagenDansk turistforening,Copenhagen, the Capital of Denmarkhttps://books.google.com/books?id189849who garnered support from the local fishing merchants against the king by granting them special privileges.sfnBooth20039In the mid 1330s, the first land assessment of the city was published.sfnBooth20039

With the establishment of theKalmar Union(13971523) betweenDenmark,NorwayandSweden, by about 1416 Copenhagen had emerged as the capital of Denmark whenEric of Pomeraniamoved his seat to Copenhagen Castle.cite bookChristine IngebritsenScandinavia in World Politicshttps://books.google.com/books?id1 January 2006Rowman & Littlefield978-0-7425-0966-57–SfnChristopher200678The University of Copenhagen was inaugurated on 1 June 1479 by KingChristian I of DenmarkChristian I, following approval from PopeSixtus IV.cite webhttp://introduction.ku.dk/presentation/history/History of the UniversityUniversity of Copenhagen12 November 2013The university's Christian role in Danish society was forced to change during theProtestant Reformationin the late 1530s, and it shifted from its Roman Catholic origins.
article.heading: 16th and 17th centuries
article.paragraph: See alsoReformation in Denmark–Norway and HolsteinIn disputes prior to the Reformation of 1536, the city which had been faithful toChristian II of DenmarkChristian II, who was Catholic, was successfully besieged in 1523 by the forces ofFrederik I of DenmarkFrederik I, who supportedLutheranism. Copenhagen's defences were reinforced with a series of towers along the city wall. After an extended siege from July 1535 to July 1536, during which the city supported Christian II's alliance withMalmandLbeck, it was finally forced to capitulate toChristian III of DenmarkChristian III. During the second half of the century, the city prospered from increased trade across theBaltic SeaBalticsupported by Dutch shipping.Christoffer Valkendorff, a high-ranking statesman, defended the city's interests and contributed to its development.The Netherlands had also become primarily Protestant, as were northern German states.

During the reign ofChristian IV of DenmarkChristian IVbetween 1588 and 1648, Copenhagen had dramatic growth as a city. On his initiative at the beginning of the 17th century, two important buildings were completed onSlotsholmen: theTjhus MuseumTjhus ArsenalandBrsen, the stock exchange. To foster international trade, theDanish East India CompanyEast India Companywas founded in 1616. To the east of the city, inspired by Dutch planning, the king developed the district ofChristianshavnwith canals and ramparts. It was initially intended to be a fortified trading centre but ultimately became part of Copenhagen.cite webhttp://www.denstoredanske.dk/Danmarks_geografi_og_historie/Danmarks_geografi/K%c3%b8benhavn/K%c3%b8benhavn/K%c3%b8benhavn_-_historie/K%c3%b8benhavn_(Historie_-_Efter_Reformationen)Københavns historie efter Reformationen''Den Store Danske''14 November 2013DanishChristian IV also sponsored an array of ambitious building projects includingRosenborg Slotand theRundetrn.sfnHarding200938In 165859, the city withstood a siege by theSwedenSwedesunderCharles X Gustav of SwedenCharles Xand successfully repelledAssault on Copenhagen (1659)a major assault.

By 1661, Copenhagen had asserted its position as capital of Denmark and Norway. All the major institutions were located there, as was the fleet and most of the army. The defences were further enhanced with the completion of theKastellet, CopenhagenCitadelin 1664 and the extension ofChristianshavns Voldwith its bastions in 1692, leading to the creation of a new base for the fleet atHolmen, CopenhagenNyholm.cite webhttp://www.denstoredanske.dk/Samfund,_jura_og_politik/Milit%C3%A6r/S%C3%B8v%C3%A6rnet/HolmenHolmenDen Store Danske23 November 2013Danish
article.heading: 18th century

link.part: A mansion at Amalienborg inFrederiksstaden(1750), part of theAmalienborg Palace

article.paragraph: Copenhagen lost around 22,000 of its population of 65,000 to theThe plague during the Great Northern Warplaguein 1711.sfnWoodward199810The city was also struck by two major fires which destroyed much of its infrastructure.SfnChristopher200678TheCopenhagen Fire of 1728was the largest in the history of Copenhagen. It began on the evening of 20 October, and continued to burn until the morning of 23 October, destroying approximately 28% of the city, leaving some 20% of the population homeless. No less than 47% of the medieval section of the city was completely lost. Along with theCopenhagen fire of 17951795 fire, it is the main reason that few traces of the old town can be found in the modern city.Raabyemagle, p. 16.cite bookLauringKåreByen brænder86–88

A substantial amount of rebuilding followed. In 1733, work began on the royal residence ofChristiansborg Palace (1st)Christiansborg Palacewhich was completed in 1745. In 1749, development of the prestigious district ofFrederiksstadenwas initiated. Designed byNicolai Eigtvedin theRococostyle, its centre contained the mansions which now formAmalienborgAmalienborg Palace.cite webhttp://arkark.dk/building.aspx?buildingidFrederiksstaden, Københavnarkark.dk14 November 2013DanishMajor extensions to the naval base ofHolmen naval baseHolmenwere undertaken while the city's cultural importance was enhanced with theRoyal Danish TheatreRoyal Theatreand theRoyal Danish Academy of Fine ArtsRoyal Academy of Fine Arts.cite webhttp://www.denstoredanske.dk/Danmarks_geografi_og_historie/Danmarks_geografi/K%c3%b8benhavn/K%c3%b8benhavn/K%c3%b8benhavn_-_historie/K%c3%b8benhavns_historie_1728-1914Københavns historie 1728–1914''Den Store Danske''14 November 2013Danish

In the second half of the 18th century, Copenhagen benefitted from Denmark's neutrality during the wars between Europe's main powers, allowing it to play an important role in trade between the states around the Baltic Sea. After Christiansborg was destroyed by fire in 1794 and another fire caused serious damage to the city in 1795, work began on the classical Copenhagen landmark ofHjbro PladswhileNytorvandGammel Torvwere converged."Kbenhavns historie 17281914",Den Store Danske.da iconRetrieved 14 November 2013.
article.heading: 19th century
article.paragraph: On 2 April 1801, aUnited Kingdom of Great Britain and IrelandBritishfleet under the command ofHyde Parker (admiral)Admiral Sir Hyde Parkerdefeated aDenmarkNorwayDanish-NorwegianRoyal Dano-Norwegian Navyfleetanchored near Copenhagen. Vice-AdmiralHoratio Nelson, 1st Viscount NelsonHoratio Nelsonled the main attack.SfnNelson2005247He famously disobeyed Parker's order to withdraw, destroying many of the Dano-Norwegian ships before a truce was agreed.sfnCowie1990130Copenhagen is often considered to be Nelson's hardest-fought battle, surpassing even the heavy fighting atBattle of TrafalgarTrafalgar.SfnPocock1994229It was during this battle that Lord Nelson was said to have "put the telescope to the blind eye" in order not to see Admiral Parker's signal toCeasefirecease fire.Cite newshttp://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/court_and_social/article2372230.eceCopenhagen's second battle remembered – 200 years onThe TimesPeterDavies3 September 2007File:Thoraldsens Museum.jpgthumbleftGottlieb Bindesbll'sThorvaldsen Museum(1848)TheBattle of Copenhagen (1807)Second Battle of Copenhagen(or the Bombardment of Copenhagen) (16 August 5 September 1807) was from a British point of view apreemptive warpreemptive attackon Copenhagen, targeting the civilian population in order to seize theRoyal Dano-Norwegian NavyDano-Norwegian fleet.SfnSmith1998204But from a Danish point of view the battle was a terror bombardment on their capital. Particularly notable was the use of incendiaryCongreve rockets(containing phosphorus, which cannot be extinguished with water) that randomly hit the city. Few houses with straw roofs remained after the bombardment. The largest church,Church of Our Lady (Copenhagen)Vor frue kirke, was destroyed by the sea artillery. Several historians consider this battle the firstTerrorismterror attackagainst a major European city in modern times.cite webhttp://www.britishbattles.com/waterloo/battle-copenhagen.htmThe Battle of CopenhagenBritishBattles.com15 November 2013cite webhttp://www.denstoredanske.dk/Danmarks_geografi_og_historie/Danmarks_historie/Danmark_1536-1849/K%C3%B8benhavns_bombardement?highlightKøbenhavns bombardement''Den Store Danske''15 November 2013Danish

File:KBH 1890-1900.jpgrightthumbSlotsholmencanal, as seen from theBrsenbuilding (18901900). In the background from left to right:Church of the Holy Ghost, CopenhagenChurch of the Holy Ghost,Rundetrn,Trinitatis ChurchTrinity Church,St. Nicholas' Church, CopenhagenSt. Nicholas Church(before the spire was rebuilt) andChurch of HolmenHolmen ChurchThe British landed 30,000 men and surrounded Copenhagen.The attack continued for the next three days, killing some 2,000 civilians and destroying most of the city.The devastation was so great because Copenhagen relied on anFortifications of Copenhagenold defence-linewhose limited range could not reach the British ships and theirRange of a projectilelonger-rangeartillery.sfnHinde1973168

Despite the disasters of the early 19th century, Copenhagen experienced a period of intense cultural creativity known as theDanish Golden Age. Painting prospered underC.W. Eckersbergand his students whileC.F. HansenandGottlieb Bindesbllbrought aNeoclassical architectureNeoclassicallook to the city's architecture.cite webhttp://www.guldalder.dk/Guide til Dansk GuldalderGolden Days15 November 2013DanishIn the early 1850s, the ramparts of the city were opened to allow new housing to be built aroundThe Lakes, CopenhagenThe Lakes(lang-daSøerne) that bordered the old defences to the west. By the 1880s, the districts ofNrrebroandVesterbro, CopenhagenVesterbrodeveloped to accommodate those who came from the provinces to participate in the city's industrialization. This dramatic increase of space was long overdue, as not only were the old ramparts out of date as a defence system but badsanitationin the old city had to be overcome. From 1886, the west rampart (Vestvolden) was flattened, allowing major extensions to the harbour leading to the establishment of theFreeport of Copenhagen189294.cite webhttp://www.denstoredanske.dk/Danmarks_geografi_og_historie/Danmarks_geografi/K%C3%B8benhavn/K%C3%B8benhavns_HavnKøbenhavns HavnDen Store DanskeDanish24 November 2013Electricity came in 1892 with electric trams in 1897. The spread of housing to areas outside the old ramparts brought about a huge increase in the population. In 1840, Copenhagen was inhabited by approximately 120,000 people. By 1901, it had some 400,000 inhabitants.
article.heading: 20th century
article.paragraph: By the beginning of the 20th century, Copenhagen had become a thriving industrial and administrative city. With its newCopenhagen City Hallcity hallandCopenhagen Central Stationrailway station, its centre was drawn towards the west.New housing developments grew up inBrnshjandValbywhileFrederiksbergbecame an enclave within the city of Copenhagen.cite webhttp://www.denstoredanske.dk/Danmarks_geografi_og_historie/Danmarks_geografi/Danmarks_kommuner/Frederiksberg_Kommune/Frederiksberg_Kommune_(Historie)Frederiksberg Kommune - historie''Den Store Danske''15 November 2013DanishThe northern part ofAmagerand Valby were also incorporated into the City of Copenhagen in 190102.cite webhttp://kobenhavnshistorie.dk/bog/khsd/1900/1900.htmlSteffen LinvaldKøbenhavns hvornår skete detKøbenhavn24 November 2013Danish

As a result of Denmark's neutrality in theFirst World War, Copenhagen prospered from trade with both Britain and Germany while the city's defences were kept fully manned by some 40,000 soldiers for the duration of the war.cite webhttp://dendigitalebyport.byhistorie.dk/monumenter/artikel.aspx?xidJan BaltzersenDenmark and Southern Jutland during the First World WarDansk Center for ByhistorieNovember 2013

In the1920sthere were serious shortages of goods and housing. Plans were drawn up to demolish the old part of Christianshavn and to get rid of the worst of the city's slum areas.sfnSchaldemose2005161However, it was not until the 1930s that substantial housing developments ensued,cite webhttp://www.denstoredanske.dk/Danmarks_geografi_og_historie/Danmarks_geografi/K%C3%B8benhavn/K%C3%B8benhavn/K%C3%B8benhavn_-_historie/K%C3%B8benhavns_historie_siden_1914?highlightKøbenhavns historie siden 1914''Den Store Danske''15 November 2013Danishwith the demolishment of one side of Christianhavn'sTorvegadein order to build five large blocks of flats.sfnSchaldemose2005161
article.heading: World War II
article.paragraph: See alsoDenmark in World War IIDanish resistance movementDuringDenmark in World War IIWorld War II in Denmark, Copenhagen wasOccupation of Denmarkoccupied by German troopsalong with the rest of the country from 9 April 1940 until 4 May 1945. German leaderAdolf Hitlerhoped that Denmark would be "a modelprotectorate"Henning Poulsen, "Dansk Modstand og Tysk Politik" ("Danish opposition and German Politics") inJyske Historiker71(1995), p.10.and initially theNazismNaziauthorities sought to arrive at an understanding with the Danish government. TheDanish Folketing election, 19431943 Danish parliamentary electionwas also allowed to take place, with only theCommunist Party of DenmarkCommunist Partyexcluded. But in August 1943, after the government's collaboration with the occupation forces collapsed, several ships werescuttlingscuttledin Copenhagen Harbour by theRoyal Danish Navyto prevent their use by the Germans. Around that time the NazisRacial policy of Nazi Germanystarted to arrest Jews, although most managed to escape toSweden.cite webhttp://denmark.dk/en/society/history/occupation/The Occupation of DenmarkDenmark.dk15 November 2013Danish

link.part: The RAF's bombing ofGestapoheadquarters in March 1945 was coordinated with the Danish resistance movement

article.paragraph: In 1945Ole Lippman, leader of the Danish section of theSpecial Operations Executive, invited the BritishRoyal Air Forceto assist their operations by attacking Nazi headquarters in Copenhagen. Accordingly,Air vice-marshalAir Vice-MarshalBasil EmbrySir Basil Embrydrew up plans for a spectacular precision attack on theSicherheitsdienstandGestapobuilding, the former offices of theShell Oil Company. Political prisoners were kept in the attic to prevent an air raid, so the RAF had to bomb the lower levels of the building.cite webhttp://www.milhist.dk/besattelsen/shell/shell.htmlThe Bombing of the Shellhus on March 21, 1945Klaus VelschowDansk Militærhistorie21 March 19459 March 2013

File:People celebrating the liberation of Denmark. 5th May 1945. At Strget in Copenhagen..jpgthumbPeople celebrating theliberation of Denmarkat Strget in Copenhagen, 5 May 1945. Germany surrendered two days laterThe attack, known as "Operation Carthage", came on 22 March 1945, in three small waves. In the first wave, all six planes (carrying one bomb each) hit their target, but one of the aircraft crashed near Frederiksberg Girls School. Because of this crash four of the planes in the two following waves assumed the school was the military target, and aimed their bombs at the school leading to the death of 123 civilians (of which 87 were schoolchildren).However, 18 of the 26 political prisoners in the Shell Building managed to escape while the Gestapo archives were completely destroyed.

On 8 May 1945 Copenhagen was officially liberated by British troops commanded byField MarshalBernard Montgomerywho supervised the surrender of 30,000 Germans situated around the capital.cite webThe Occupation of Denmarkhttp://Denmark.dk/en/society/history/occupation/Denmark.dk10 May 2014
article.heading: Post-war decades
article.paragraph: File:SHL - Black Diamond.jpgthumbleftTheBlack Diamond (library)Black Diamond(1999)Shortly after the end of the war, an innovative urban development project known as theFinger Planwas introduced in 1947, encouraging the creation of new housing and businesses interspersed with large green areas along five "fingers" stretching out from the city centre along theS-trainroutes.cite bookRegional Development Policies in OECD Countrieshttps://books.google.com/books?id4 November 2010OECD Publishing978-92-64-08722-4357sfnCervero1998132With the expansion of the welfare state and women entering the work force, schools, nurseries, sports facilities and hospitals were established across the city. As a result of student unrest in the late 1960s, the former Bdsmandsstrde Barracks inChristianshavnwas occupied, leading to the establishment ofFreetown Christianiain September 1971.cite webhttp://www.kk.dk/da/om-kommunen/fakta-og-statistik/historie-og-udvikling/koebenhavns-historieKøbenhavns historieKøbenhavns Kommune15 November 2013Danish

File:Bridge over resund.jpgthumbresund Bridge(1999)Motor traffic in the city grew significantly and in 1972 the trams were replaced by buses. From the 1960s, on the initiative of the young architectJan Gehl, pedestrian streets and cycle tracks were created in the city centre.cite webhttp://cphpost.dk/news/national/%E2%80%98copenhagenizing%E2%80%99-world-one-city-timeElise Beacom'Copenhagenizing' the world, one city at a time''the Copenhagen post''10 November 201224 November 2013Activity in the port of Copenhagen declined with the closure of the Holmen naval base.Copenhagen Airportunderwent considerable expansion, becoming a hub for theNordic countries. In the 1990s, large-scale housing developments were realized in the harbour area and in the west ofAmager.The national library'sBlack Diamond (library)Black Diamondbuilding on the waterfront was completed in 1999.cite webhttp://en.danskarkitekturguide.dk/node/6855The Black Diamond''Danish architecture guide''15 November 2013Danish
article.heading: 2000 to present
article.paragraph: File:Copenaghen Opera House.jpgthumbleftCopenhagen Opera House(2004)Since the summer of2000, Copenhagen and the Swedish city ofMalmhave been connected by theresund Bridge, which carries rail and road traffic. As a result, Copenhagen has become the centre of a larger metropolitan area spanning both nations. The bridge has brought about considerable changes in the publictransport networktransport systemand has led to the extensive redevelopment ofAmager.The city's service and trade sectors have developed while a number of banking and financial institutions have been established. Educational institutions have also gained importance, especially theUniversity of Copenhagenwith its 35,000 students.cite webhttp://danmarkshistorien.dk/leksikon-og-kilder/vis/materiale/koebenhavn/KøbenhavnDanmarkshistorien.dk15 November 2013DanishAnother important development for the city has been theCopenhagen Metro, the underground railway system which opened in 2000 with additions until 2007, transporting some 54 million passengers by 2011.cite webhttp://www.railway-technology.com/projects/copenhagen/Copenhagen Metro, Denmarkrailwaytechnology.com23 November 2013

On the cultural front, the lavishCopenhagen Opera House, a gift to the city from the shipping magnateMrsk Mc-Kinney Mlleron behalf of the A.P. Mller foundation, was completed in 2004.cite webhttp://www.henninglarsen.com/projects/0400-0599/0553-the-opera-copenhagen.aspxThe Opera in CopenhagenHenning Larsen Architects16 November 2013In December 2009 Copenhagen gained international prominence when it hosted the worldwide climate meetingCOP15.cite webhttp://unfccc.int/meetings/copenhagen_dec_2009/meeting/6295.phpCopenhagen Climate Change Conference - December 2009United Nations15 November 2013clear all
article.heading: Geography
article.paragraph: File:Copenhagen skyline.jpgthumbupright=1.5rightSkyline of the old city core of Copenhagen.File:Copenhagen 12.57744E 55.66605N.jpgthumbSatellite viewCopenhagen is part of theresund Region, which consists ofZealand,Lolland-FalsterandBornholminDenmarkandScaniainSweden.cite webhttp://www.oresundsregionen.org/en/about-the-oeresund-regionWhat is the Øresund Region?Øresund17 November 2013DanishIt is located on the eastern shore of the island ofZealand (Denmark)Zealand, partly on the island ofAmagerand on a number of natural and artificial islets between the two. Copenhagen faces theresundto the east, the strait of water that separates Denmark fromSweden, and which connects theNorth Seawith theBaltic Sea. TheSwedenSwedishtowns ofMalmandLandskronalie on the Swedish side of the sound directly across from Copenhagen.cite webhttp://www.danishnet.com/info.php/travel/copenhagen-19.htmlCopenhagen (København), DenmarkDanishnet.com16 November 2013By road, Copenhagen isconvert42kmnorthwest ofMalm, Sweden,convert85kmnortheast ofNstved,convert164kmnortheast ofOdense,convert295kmeast ofEsbjergandconvert188kmsoutheast ofAarhusby sea and road viaSjaellands Odde.Google mapshttps://maps.google.co.uk/maps?q24 November 2013

The city centre lies in the area originally defined by the oldrampart (fortification)ramparts, which are still referred to as theFortification Ring, CopenhagenFortification Ring(Fstningsringen) and kept as a partial green band around it.cite webhttp://www.kk.dk/da/brugbyen/brug-steder-i-byen/groenne-omraader/parker/indre-byParker I Indre ByDanishCopenhagen Municipality25 November 2013Then come the late 19th and early 20th century residential neighbourhoods ofsterbro,Nrrebro,Vesterbro, CopenhagenVesterbroandAmagerbro. The outlying areas ofKongens Enghave,Valby,Vigerslev,Vanlse,Brnshj,UtterslevandSundby, CopenhagenSundbyfollowed from 1920 to 1960. They consist mainly of residential housing and apartments often enhanced with parks and greenery.
article.heading: Topography
article.paragraph: The central area of the city consists of relatively low-lying flat ground formed bymorainesfrom the last ice age while the hilly areas to the north and west frequently rise toconvert50monabove sea level. The slopes ofValbyandBrnshjreach heights of overconvert30mon, divided by valleys running from the northeast to the southwest. Close to the centre are theThe Lakes, CopenhagenCopenhagen lakesof Sortedams S, Peblinge S and Sankt Jrgens S.cite webhttp://www.denstoredanske.dk/Danmarks_geografi_og_historie/Danmarks_geografi/K%C3%B8benhavn/K%C3%B8benhavn/K%C3%B8benhavn_-_geografiKøbenhavn - geografi''Den Store Danske''16 November 2013Danish

Copenhagen rests on a subsoil of flint-layered limestone deposited in theDanianperiod some 60 to 66 million years ago. Somegreensand (geology)greensandfrom theSelandianis also present. There are a few faults in the area, the most important of which is the Carlsberg fault which runs northwest to southeast through the centre of the city.cite webhttp://geocenter.dk/xpdf/geoviden-4-2005.pdfLars Nielsen, Alexander Lassen, Hans ThyboCarlsbergforkastningen''Geoviden''48–11200517 November 2013DanishDuring the last ice age, glaciers eroded the surface leaving a layer of moraines up toconvert15monthick.cite webhttp://www.denstoredanske.dk/Danmarks_geografi_og_historie/Danmarks_geografi/K%c3%b8benhavn/K%c3%b8benhavn/K%c3%b8benhavn_(Geologi)København - geologi''Den Store Danske''17 November 2013Danish
article.heading: Beaches
article.paragraph: File:Amager Strandpark - kite surfers.jpgthumbleftAmager StrandparkCopenhagen and the surrounding areas have three beaches with a total of approx.convert8km0offof sandy shores within 30 minutes cycling from the city centre.citation neededJuly 2015These includeAmager Strandpark, which opened in 2005 with aconvert2km0onlong artificial island and a total ofconvert4.6km1onof beaches, located just 15 minutes by bicycle or a few minutes by metro from the city centre.cite webhttp://www.amager-strand.dk/content/strandenStrandenAmagerstrand21 November 2013Danish

The beaches are supplemented by a system ofCopenhagen Harbour BathsHarbour Bathsalong the Copenhagen waterfront. The first and most popular of these is located atIslands Bryggeand has won international acclaim for its design.cite webhttp://www.architecture-page.com/go/people/profiles/bjarke-ingels-group2007 IOC Honorable Mentionap architecture-page5 January 2009
article.heading: Climate
article.paragraph: File:Frederiksberg Palace from above (winter).JPGthumbFrederiksberg Palacein the snowCopenhagen is in theoceanic climatezone (Kppen climate classificationKppen:Cfb ).cite webhttp://www.weatheronline.co.uk/reports/climate/Denmark.htmDenmarkWeather Online17 November 2013Its weather is subject tolow pressure arealow-pressure systemsfrom theAtlantic OceanAtlanticwhich result in unstable conditions throughout the year. Apart from slightly higher rainfall from July to September, precipitation is moderate. While there can be snow from late December to late April, there can also be rain with average temperatures around the freezing point.cite webhttp://www.weather-and-climate.com/average-monthly-Rainfall-Temperature-Sunshine,copenhagen,DenmarkAverage weather in Copenhagen, DenmarkWorld Weather and Climate Information17 November 2013Danish

June is the sunniest month of the year with an average of about eight hours of sunshine a day. July is the warmest month with an average daytime high of 22 C. By contrast, the average hours of sunshine are less than two per day in November and only one and a half per day from December to February. In the spring, it gets warmer again with from four to six hours of sunshine per day from March to May. February is the driest month of the year.cite webhttp://www.dmi.dk/vejr/arkiver/normaler-og-ekstremer/klimanormaler-dk/KlimanormalerDanmarks Meteorologiske Institut1 February 2014DanishExceptional weather conditions can bring as much as 50 cm of snow to Copenhagen in a 24-hour period during the winter monthscite webhttp://www.cph.dk/CPH/DK/MAIN/Foer+afrejse/Vejr+og+flyvning/Kl%C3%A6dt+p%C3%A5+til+vinteren.htmKøbenhavns Lufthavn er klædt på til vinterenCPH17 November 2013Danishwhile summer temperatures have been known to rise to heights ofconvert33°C0.cite webhttp://www.bt.dk/danmark/varmeste-dag-i-37-aarExceptionel varm sommerdag i København''BT''21 September 201217 November 2013Danish

Because of Copenhagen's northern latitude, the number of daylight hours varies considerably between summer and winter. On the summer solstice, the sun rises at 04:26 and sets at 21:58, providing 17 hours 32 minutes of daylight. On the winter solstice, it rises at 08:37 and sets at 15:39 with 7 hours and 1 minute of daylight. There is therefore a difference of 10 hours and 31 minutes in the length of days and nights between the summer and winter solstices .cite webhttp://www.torbenhermansen.dk/almanak/almanak.php#Sol op/nedAlmanak17 November 2013Danish
article.heading: Administration
Districts
article.paragraph: MainDistricts of CopenhagenFile:Districts of Copenhagen urban area.jpgthumbrightDistricts ofCopenhagen MunicipalityTheconurbationof Copenhagen includes theMunicipalities of DenmarkmunicipalitiesofCopenhagen MunicipalityCopenhagen,Dragr MunicipalityDragr,Frederiksberg MunicipalityFrederiksbergandTrnby MunicipalityTrnby, with a total population of 704,108 at the start of 2012.cite webhttp://www.statistikbanken.dk/BEF1A07Statistics Denmark, table BEF1A07: Population 1 January by region, age, sex, marital statusStatistikbanken.dk9 March 2013AfterCopenhagen Municipality, the second largest is Frederiksberg Municipality, an enclave inside Copenhagen Municipality. Both are contained in the largerCapital Region of Denmark(langda''Region Hovedstaden''), containing most of theurban area of Copenhagen.

Since a reform in 200608, Copenhagen Municipality has been divided into ten districts (bydele):cite webhttp://www.kk.dk/da/om-kommunen/fakta-og-statistik/statistik-og-historie/saadan-er-byen-inddelt/bydeleKøbenhavns bydeleKøbenhavns Kommune31 December 2012Indre By,sterbro,Nrrebro,Vesterbro/Kongens Enghave,Valby,Vanlse,Brnshj-Husum,Bispebjerg,Amager st, andAmager Vest. Neighbourhoods of Copenhagen includeSlotsholmenFrederiksstaden,Islands Brygge,Holmen, CopenhagenHolmen,Freetown ChristianiaChristiania,Carlsberg (district)Carlsberg,Sluseholmen,Amagerbro,restad,Nordhavnen,Bellahj,Brnshj,Ryparken, andVigerslev.
article.heading: Municipal government
article.paragraph: FurtherCopenhagen MunicipalityList of lord mayors of CopenhagenFile:Copenhagen City Hall.jpgthumbleftCopenhagen City Hall, situated onCity Hall Square, CopenhagenCity Hall SquareCopenhagen Municipality is distinct from the wider Copenhagen urban area. The seat of Copenhagen'smunicipal councilis theCopenhagen City Hall(Kbenhavns Rdhus). The council is chaired by the Lord MayorcurrentlyFrank Jensenwho oversees the civic duties of the fifty-five representatives of the council.cite webhttp://www.kk.dk/da/om-kommunen/politisk-organisation/borgerrepraesentationBorgerrepræsentationenKøbenhavns KommuneDanish28 November 2013The council usually meets every other week at 17:30 on a Thursday.They discuss a range of issues including labour and employment, business growth, economics, international cooperation and IT, urban planning, housing and construction, and young, old, and disabled peoples' issues, healthcare, and traffic, with a central focus on making the city sustainable and meeting environmental and health targets.cite webhttp://www.kk.dk/da/om-kommunen/indsatsomraader-og-politikker?elementIndsatsområder og politikkerKøbenhavns KommuneDanish28 November 2013File:Frank Jensen Bogforum10.jpgthumbrightFrank Jensen, Lord Mayor of theCopenhagen Municipality

All members of the council are elected every four years. In the municipal elections in November 2013, theSocial Democrats (Denmark)Social Democratsremained in first place with 27.8% of the vote (down by 2.2% from 2009), while theRedGreen Alliance (Denmark)Red-Green Alliancewas in second place with 19.5%.cite webhttp://kmdvalg.dk/kv/2013/k84982101.htmKommunalvalg d. 19. november 2013: København KommuneKMD29 November 2013Danishcite webhttp://www.internationalviewpoint.org/spip.php?article3189Result of the municipal and regional election in Denmark 19th of November 2013International Viewpoint29 November 2013The Social Democrats have claimed the office of mayor for the past 110 years.cite webhttp://nyhederne.tv2.dk/samfund/2013-11-18-s-st%C3%A5r-til-d%C3%A5rligste-valg-i-kbh-nogensindeS står til dårligste valg i Kbh nogensindeRitzau18 November 201318 November 2013

The municipal government is divided into seven administrative departments: Employment and Integration, Culture and Leisure, Health and Care, Finance, Child and Youth, Social Services, and Technical and Environmental Administration.cite webhttp://www.kk.dk/da/om-kommunen/kontakt/kontakt-kommunenKontakt en forvaltningKøbenhavns KommuneDanish28 November 2013It has six political committees and a finance committee. The annual budget for the city is proposed in August and finalized in October and the annual report is published in May of every year. The accounting firmDeloitteis responsible for auditing the City of Copenhagen's accounts.cite web http://www.kk.dk/da/om-kommunen/regnskab-og-budget?elementRegnskab og budgetKøbenhavns KommuneDanish28 November 2013
article.heading: Law and order
article.paragraph: Most of Denmark's top legal courts and institutions are based in Copenhagen. A modern stylecourtcourt of justice,Hof- og Stadsretten, was introduced in Denmark, specifically for Copenhagen, byJohann Friedrich Struenseein 1771.cite webhttp://www.denstoredanske.dk/Samfund,_jura_og_politik/Jura/Retshistorie/Hof-_og_StadsrettenHof- og StadsrettenGyldendal28 November 2013Now known as theCopenhagen Court HouseCity Court of Copenhagen(Kobenhavns Byret), it is the largest of the 24 city courts in Denmark with jurisdiction over the municipalities of Copenhagen,DragrandTrnby. With its 42 judges, it has a Probate Division, an Enforcement Division and a Registration and Notorial Acts Division while bankruptcy is handled by theMaritime and Commercial Court (Denmark)Maritime and Commercial Court of Copenhagen.cite webhttp://www.domstol.dk/KobenhavnsByret/Pages/TheCityCourtofCopenhagen.aspxThe City Court of CopenhagenDanmarks Domstole: Københavns Byret29 November 2013Established in 1862, the Maritime and Commercial Court (S- og Handelsretten) also hears commercial cases including those relating to trade marks, marketing practices and competition for the whole of Denmark.cite webhttp://www.domstol.dk/om/otherlanguages/english/thedanishjudicialsystem/maritimeandcommercialcourt/Pages/default.aspxThe Copenhagen Maritime and Commercial CourtDanmarks Domstole29 November 2013Denmark'sSupreme Court of DenmarkSupreme Court(Hjesteret), located inChristiansborg Palaceon Prins Jrgens Grd in the centre of Copenhagen, is the country's final court of appeal. Handling civil and criminal cases from the subordinate courts, it has two chambers which each hear all types of cases.cite webhttp://www.denstoredanske.dk/Samfund,_jura_og_politik/Jura/Retspleje_og_domstole/H%C3%B8jesteret?highlightHøjesteret''Den Store Danske''29 November 2013Danish

File:Police HQ Copenhagen.JPGthumbright''Politigrden'', the police headquartersTheDanish National Policeand Copenhagen Police headquarters is situated in the Neoclassical-inspiredCopenhagen Police HeadquartersPolitigrdenbuilding built in 191824 under architectsHack KampmannandHolger JacobsenHolger Alfred Jacobsen. The building also contains administration, management, emergency department and radio service offices.cite webhttp://www.visitcopenhagen.com/copenhagen/police-headquarters-gdk559779Police headquartersVisitcopenhagen.com28 November 2013In their efforts to deal with drugs, the police have noted considerable success in the two special drug consumption rooms opened by the city where addicts can use sterile needles and receive help from nurses if necessary. While drugs are still illegal, police do not prosecute addicts using the rooms. Deputy Chief Superintendent Kaj Majlund commented, "You have to find new ways to deal with drug addicts. You can't succeed by putting them into jail."cite webhttp://voiceofrussia.com/news/2013_10_30/Britain-eyes-Denmarks-safe-drug-room-experience-4408/Britain eyes Denmark's safe drug room experienceThe Voice of Russia, BBC30 October 20132 December 2013

TheCopenhagen Fire Departmentforms the largest municipal fire brigade in Denmark with some 500 fire and ambulance personnel, 150 administration and service workers, and 35 workers in prevention.cite webhttp://www.brand.kk.dk/OmOs/Hvem%20er%20vi/English.aspxCopenhagen Fire BrigadeKøbenhavns Kommune28 November 2013The brigade began as the Copenhagen Royal Fire Brigade on 9 July 1687 under King Christian V. After the passing of the Copenhagen Fire Act on 18 May 1868, on 1 August 1870 the Copenhagen Fire Brigade became a municipal institution in its own right.cite webhttp://www.brand.kk.dk/OmOs/Hvem%20er%20vi/English/History.aspxHistory of the Copenhagen Fire BrigadeKøbenhavns Kommune28 November 2013The fire department has its headquarters in theCopenhagen Central Fire Stationwhich was designed byLudvig Fengerin theHistoricism (art)Historiciststyle and inaugurated in 1892.cite webhttp://www.brand.kk.dk/OmOs/Hvem%20er%20vi/Hvor%20bor%20vi/Hovedbrandstationen.aspxHovedbrandstationenKøbenhavns Bransvæsen7 December 2013Danish
article.heading: Environmental planning
article.paragraph: MainEnergy in DenmarkCopenhagen is recognized as one of the most environmentally friendly cities in the world.cite webhttp://green-buzz.net/environment/10-worlds-greenest-cities/10 World's Greenest Cities27 April 201129 November 2012The municipal policy is to reduceglobal warmingCO2 emissionsby 20% before the end of 2015.cite webhttp://www.kk.dk/vejpark.aspxstreet lights in CopenhagenKøbenhavns Kommune5 January 2009In 2001 a large offshorewind farmwas built just off the coast of Copenhagen atMiddelgrunden. It produces about 4% of the city's energy.cite webhttp://www.cece.dk/EE0911AA-D9A1-49E8-9CA2-332E37BBA568https://web.archive.org/web/20070706184255/http://www.cece.dk/EE0911AA-D9A1-49E8-9CA2-332E37BBA5686 July 2007Environmental Capital of EuropeCopenhagen, Environmental Capital of Europe5 January 2009Years of substantial investment insewage treatmenthave improvedwater qualityin the harbour to an extent that the inner harbour can be used for swimming with facilities at a number of locations.cite webhttp://www.dac.dk/en/dac-cities/sustainable-cities/all-cases/water/copenhagen-from-sewer-to-harbour-bath/?bbredirectCopenhagen: From sewer to harbour bathDAC & Cities27 November 2013File:Copenhagen view from North port 20090818 41.JPGthumb200pxleftMiddelgrundenoffshore wind farm

Copenhagen aims to becarbon-neutralby2025. Commercial and residential buildings are to reduce electricity consumption by 20 percent and 10 percent respectively, and total heat consumption is to fall by 20 percent by 2025. Renewable energy features such as solar panels are becoming increasingly common in the newest buildings in Copenhagen. District heating will be carbon-neutral by 2025. New buildings must now be constructed according to Low Energy Class ratings and in 2020 near net-zero energy buildings. By 2025, 75% of trips should be made on foot, by bike, or by using public transit. The city plans that 20-30% of cars will run on electricity orbiofuelby 2025. The investment is estimated at $472 million public funds and $4.78 billion private funds.Copenhagen's ambitious push to be carbon-neutral by 2025Guardian 12 April 2013

The city's architectural planning authorities continue to take full account of these priorities. Special attention is given both to climate issues and efforts to ensure maximum application ofLow-energy houselow-energy standards. Priorities includeWater conservationrecycling rainwater,green roofsand efficientwaste managementsolutions. In city planning, streets and squares are to be designed to encourage cycling and walking rather than driving.cite webhttp://kk.sites.itera.dk/apps/kk_pub2/pdf/961_BLdBaJTGzV.pdfCopenhagen City of Architecture: The architecture policy of the City of CopenhagenTechnical and Environmental Administration, City of Copenhagen20102 December 2013

As a result of its commitment to high environmental standards, Copenhagen has been praised for itsgreen economy, ranked as the top green city for the second time in the 2014Global Green Economy Index (GGEI).cite webhttp://dualcitizeninc.com/GGEI-Report2014.pdf2014 Global Green Economy IndexDual Citizen LLC19 October 201419 October 2014cite webhttp://www.meetincopenhagen.com/news-and-events/business-news/new-green-city-survey-ranks-copenhagen-no-1New green city survey ranks Copenhagen No. 1MeetinCopenhagen12 September 201217 November 2013It has also received the title of "European Green Capital 2014" as a result of its environmental record and its ambitious goals. Mention was made of the city's efforts to work with companies, universities and organisations in order to further green growth, the "Green Laboratory" component in its North Harbour project, and its efforts to increase the proportion of the population cycling to work to 50% by 2015.cite webhttp://europa.eu/rapid/press-release_IP-12-718_en.htmEnvironment: Copenhagen European Green Capital 2014European Commission29 June 201217 November 2013Danish
article.heading: Demographics and society

tablerow.tablehead:
Copenhagen Municipality (Q32015)
population by country of origincite webPopulation at the first day of the quarter by municipality, sex, age, marital status, ancestry, country of origin and citizenshiphttp://www.statbank.dk/statbank5a/SelectOut/PxSort.asp?fileStatistics Denmark2015-09-24

article.paragraph: <noinclude>Statistics from fourth quarter 2013 show that 439,824 (77.3%) of the population ofCopenhagen Municipality(central Copenhagen) were ofDanesDanish origin, 41,423immigrantsand 4,628 descendants from Western countries (8.1%), 56,026 immigrants and 27,099 descendants from non-Western countries (14.6%).
article.heading: Population
article.paragraph: Depending on the boundaries used, the population of Copenhagen differs. Statistics Denmark has never specified the geographical area of urban Copenhagen, but it is known to consist ofCopenhagen Municipality,Frederiksberg MunicipalityFrederiksbergand 16 of the 20 municipalities in the old countiesCopenhagen CountyCopenhagenandRoskilde CountyRoskilde, though five of them only partially.cite webhttp://www.dst.dk/pukora/epub/Nyt/2007/NR415.pdfDanmarks StatistikByopgørelse 1. januar 2007 (Largest cities of Denmark 2007)Danish31 December 2012The urban area of Copenhagen has a population of 1,246,611 inhabitants as of 2014, with a total of 1,975,361 inhabitants in the overall metropolitan area as 2014; the latter is equivalent to the local traffic area and ticket fare zones, coveringconvert2778km20off.sfnBrebbia201324Based on a 10%-isoline (data from 2002) in which at least 10% of the population commutes into central parts of the Copenhagen area, most of Zealand would be covered and this area has a population of about 2.3 million inhabitants.cite webhttp://www.bvl.aau.dk/dansk/fase1/plancher/pendler_hreg.jpgAndel af befolkningen der pendler til den centrale del a HUR-området9 March 2013

Since the opening of the resund Bridge in 2000, commuting betweenZealandandScaniainSwedenhas increased rapidly, leading to a wider, integrated area. Known as the resund Region, it has 3.8 million inhabitants (of which 2.5 million live in the Danish part of the region).cite webhttp://www.orestat.se/da/node/99Befolkning: BefolkningsvækstÖresundsStatistik och analyser6 December 2013Danish
article.heading: Religion
article.paragraph: See alsoReligion in DenmarkFile:Vor Frue Kirke Copenhagen.jpgthumbleftChurch of Our Lady (Copenhagen)Church of Our Lady, the National Cathedral of Denmark.The majority of those living in Copenhagen are members of the LutheranChurch of Denmark, although the 61.6% specifically confirming their membership by paying church taxes is well below the national average of 79.1% according to 2013 figures.cite webhttp://miliki.dk/kirke/statistik/folkekirkens-medlemstal/Medlemmer af folkekirkenMinisteriet for Ligestilling og Kirke26 November 2013DanishThere are also several other Christian communities in the city, of which the largest isRoman Catholic.cite webhttp://www.katolsk.dk/fileadmin/katolsk/User_oploads/dokumenter_bispekontoret/Noegletal_2010_Sogneoekonomi.pdfNøgletal for sogneneKatolsk.dk26 November 2013

The second most significant religion practised in the city isIslam, accounting for approximately 10% of the population.cite bookNydellMargaret K.Understanding Arabs: a contemporary guide to Arab societyIntercultural PressBoston, MA9780983955801132In 2011 they constituted 25 percent of Rotterdam, Marseilles, and Amsterdam; 20% of Malmo; 15 percent of Brussels and Birmingham; and 10 percent of London, Paris, Copenhagen, and Vienna.
Muslims in Western Europe originate from both Arab and non-Arab countries. Those in the United Kingdom are primarily from South Asia, in France from North and West Africa, in Germany from Turkey, in Belgium from Morocco, and in the Netherlands from Morocco and Turkey.cite bookFarmerBrian R.Radical Islam in the West: ideology and challenge2010McFarland & Co.Jefferson, N.C.97807864595378Muslims living in the West are also concentrated in urban area. Muslims are currently estimated to compose almost one-forth of the population of Amsterdam. one-fifth of Marseilles, and 15 percent of Paris, Brussels, and Birmingham. Muslims are currently make up approximately 10 percent of the populations in London and Copenhagen.cite bookMicklethwaitJohn[[God is Back|God is back]] how the global revival of faith is changing the world2009Penguin PressNew York9781101032411Wooldridge, AdrianMuslims are highly concentrated—they make up 24 percent of the population in Amsterdam; 20 percent in Malmo and Marseille; 15 percent in Paris, Brussels, Bradford, and Birmingham; and 10 percent or more in London and Copenhagen.While there are no official statistics, a significant portion of the estimated 175,000-200,000 Muslims in the country live in the Copenhagen urban area, with the highest concentration inNrrebroand the Vestegnen.cite webhttp://www.opensocietyfoundations.org/sites/default/files/aa-muslims-copenhagen-dn-2011111_0.pdfMuslimer i KøbenhavnOpen Society Foundations26 November 20132011Danish24, 33–38978-1-936133-10-9There are some 7,000JudaismJewsin Denmark, most of them in the Copenhagen area where there are several synagogues.cite webhttp://www.religion.dk/artikel/248461:Joededom--Joededom-i-DanmarkJødedom i DanmarkReligion-dk26 November 2013Danishclear
article.heading: Quality of living
article.paragraph: For a number of years, Copenhagen has ranked high in international surveys for itsquality of life. Its stable economy together with its education services and level of social safety make it attractive for locals and visitors alike. Although it is one of the world's most expensive cities, it is also one of the most liveable with its public transport, facilities for cyclists and its environmental policies.cite webhttp://www.bbc.com/travel/feature/20110906-living-in-copenhagenSunshine FlintLiving in CopenhagenBBCSeptember 201130 November 2013In elevating Copenhagen to "most liveable city" in 2013,Monocle (media company)Monoclepointed to its open spaces, increasing activity on the streets, city planning in favour of cyclists and pedestrians, and features to encourage inhabitants to enjoy city life with an emphasis on community, culture and cuisine.cite webhttp://monocle.com/film/affairs/most-liveable-city-copenhagen/Most liveable city: Copenhagen''Monocle''30 November 2013Other sources have ranked Copenhagen high for its business environment, accessibility, restaurants and environmental planning.cite webhttp://www.visitcopenhagen.com/copenhagen/prestigious-titles-and-rankings-copenhagenPrestigious titles and rankings to CopenhagenVisit Copenhagen6 September 201330 November 2013For students, however, Copenhagen ranks only No. 39 for student friendliness in 2012. Despite a top score for quality of living, its scores were low for employer activity and affordability.cite webhttp://universitypost.dk/article/copenhagen-high-quality-life-pricePolina ChebotarevaCopenhagen is high quality of life, but at a priceUniversity Post15 February 201230 November 2013
article.heading: Economy
article.paragraph: Copenhagen is the economic andfinancial centreof Denmark. Statistics for 2010 show that of the 350,000 people working in Copenhagen, the vast majority are employed in theservice sector, especially transport and communications, trade, and finance, while less than 10,000 work in themanufacturingmanufacturing industries. Thepublic sectorworkforce is around 110,000, including education and healthcare.cite webhttps://subsite.kk.dk/sitecore/content/Subsites/CityOfCopenhagen/SubsiteFrontpage/Press/FactsOnCopenhagen/Statistics/Labor%20market/WorkplacesByIndustry.aspxWorkplaces in Copenhagen by industry and residence of the employed, 1 January 2010City of Copenhagen25 November 2013From 2006 to 2011, the economy grew by 2.5% in Copenhagen and Copenhagen Municipality while it fell by some 4% in the rest of Denmark.cite webhttp://www.damvad.com/media/82689/erhvervsdata_kk-endelig.pdfUdvalgte indikatorer for Københavns erhvervsmæssige præstationer og rammevilkårDAMVAD14 November 201326 November 2013Danish

InDansk Industri's 2013 survey of employment factors in 96 Danish municipalities, Copenhagen came in first place for educational qualifications and for the development of private companies in recent years but fell to No. 86 in local companies' assessment of the employment climate. The survey revealed considerable dissatisfaction in the level of dialogue companies enjoyed with the municipal authorities.cite webhttp://di.dk/DI/Regionalt/Hovedstaden/Nyt%20fra%20DI%20Hovedstaden/Pages/PressemeddelelseKoebenhavnsvirksomhederefterlyserbedreerhvervsklima.aspxPressemeddelelse: Københavns virksomheder efterlyser bedre erhvervsklimaDansk Industri4 September 201318 November 2013DanishIn 2012, Copenhagen was third in the ranking of the richest cities in the world in terms of gross earnings, dropping from first place in 2009.cite webhttp://www.citymayors.com/economics/richest_cities.htmlThe most expensive and richest cities in the worldCity Mayors Economics18 November 2013In the 2011 UBS survey of prices and earnings, Copenhagen had fallen to fifth place for price levels while it held third place in gross wage levels and was said to have the highest purchasing power in terms of gross hourly wages although it was only in 12th place in terms of domestic purchasing power.cite webhttp://www.static-ubs.com/global/en/wealth_management/wealth_management_research/prices_earnings/_jcr_content/par/columncontrol/col1/linklist/link_0.1393999310.file/bGluay9wYXRoPS9jb250ZW50L2RhbS91YnMvZ2xvYmFsL3dlYWx0aF9tYW5hZ2VtZW50L3dlYWx0aF9tYW5hZ2VtZW50X3Jlc2VhcmNoL1BfTF8yMDEyX2VuLnBkZgPrices and earningsUBSSeptember 201218 November 2013Danish

File:Ny Carlsberg Bryghus.jpgthumbrightNy Carlsberg BrewhouseCopenhagen is home to a number of international companies includingMaerskA.P. Mller-Mrsk,Novo Nordisk,Carlsberg GroupCarlsbergandNovozymes.cite webhttp://www.forbes.com/global2000/The World's Biggest Public Companies18 November 201318 April 2012[[Forbes]]The city also has successful business clusters in several innovative sectors includinginformation technology,biotechnology,pharmaceuticalsandclean technology.cite webhttp://www.neweuropeaneconomy.com/home-mainmenu-51/briefing-mainmenu-86/207-copenhagen--open-for-businessCopenhagen  Open for Business''New European Economy''18 November 2013Danish

Tourism is also an increasingly important sector for Copenhagen's economy, reaching record numbers in 2012 for the third year in succession.cite webhttp://www.wonderfulcopenhagenannual.dk/UK.aspxA Record Year for Tourism: Annual Report 2012Wonderful Copenhagen18 November 2013The number of room nights reached 8.1 million, up 25% since 2008. Between 2011 and 2012, room nights increased 9.2% overall, tallying a rise of 39% for Chinese visitors. The numbers of airline and cruise passengers visiting the city were also at new highs while turnover for congress tourism reached DKK 1.2 billion with a total of 57 congresses in the year.

Copenhagen has aService-orientationservice orientedeconomy.BiologyLife scienceis a key sector with extensiveresearch and developmentactivities. In collaboration with Sweden,Medicon Valleyis being developed as a central sector of interest across the entireresund Region. Major Danish biotech companies likeNovo NordiskandLundbeck, both of which are among theList of pharmaceutical companies50 largest pharmaceutical and biotech companies in the world, are located in the greater Copenhagen area.cite webhttp://www.usatoday.com/marketplace/ibi/copenhagen.htmCopenhagen - OverviewUsatoday.Com19 May 20099 March 2013Shipping is also an import sector withA. P. Moller-Maersk GroupMaersk, the world's largestList of ship companiesshipping company, having their world headquarters in Copenhagen.

Copenhagen has some of the highest gross wages in the world.cite webhttp://www.citymayors.com/economics/richest_cities.htmlWorld's richest citiesCity Mayors5 May 2009High taxes mean that wages are reduced after mandatory deduction. Abeneficial researcher schemewith low taxation of foreign specialists has made Denmark an attractive location forImmigrationforeign labour. It is however also among the most expensive cities in Europe.cite webhttp://www.citymayors.com/economics/expensive_cities_eiu.htmlWorld's most expensive cities (EIU)City Mayors5 May 2009cite webhttp://www.citymayors.com/economics/expensive_cities2.htmlWorld's most expensive cities – RankingCity Mayors5 May 2009
article.heading: Medicon Valley
article.paragraph: MainMedicon ValleyFile:Ferring Neroport Orestad 20100810 0179F (8370660268).jpgthumbScandinavian headquarters for theSwisspharmaceutical companyFerring Pharmaceuticalswith theCopenhagen Metrometroin frontCopenhagen is rich in companies and institutions with a focus onresearch and developmentwithin thebiotechnologyandBiologylife sciencesectors.cite webhttp://www.copcap.com/BusinessOpportunities/Life%20science/backgroundLife Science in the Øresund RegionCopenhagen Capacity23 January 2014Two of theList of pharmaceutical companies50 largest pharmaceutical and biotech companies in the worldare located in theCopenhagen metropolitan area. The biotechnology and life scienceBusiness clusterclusterin Copenhagen and the rest of the resund Region is one of the strongest in Europe. Known asMedicon Valley, it is a collaborative venture supported by both Denmark and Sweden. The aim is to strengthen the region's position and to promote cooperation between companies andacademia. Hundreds of companies have been established in the area, the majority on the Danish side of the sound.cite webhttp://mediconvalleyonline.com/Organisations/?pageOrganisationsMedicon Valley Online19 November 2013Danishcite webhttp://www.mediconvalley.com/content/us3/facts/medicon_valley_brochureMedicon Valley BrochureMedicon Valley23 January 2014
article.heading: Cleantech
article.paragraph: Launched in2010, the Copenhagen Cleantech Cluster is the focal point of a cooperative effort between public authorities, universities, research institutions and cleantech companies. By 2012, the initiative involved 533 companies in the Copenhagen region, up from 396 in 2010. The service sector, with 44% of companies, was the top sector followed by wholesale and retail trade (22%) and production (20%). The cluster employed more than 85,000 people in 2010, down from 94,000 in 2008.cite webhttp://www.cphcleantech.com/media/2083427/copenhagen%20cleantech%20cluster%20monitor%202012%20samlet.pdfMonitor Copenhagen Cleantech Cluster 2012Copenhagen Cleantech Cluster20 November 2013The region's most important cleantech research institutions are theUniversity of Copenhagen,Copenhagen Business School,cite webThe win-win ways of Cleantech businessCBS Observer26 March 2009http://cbsobserver.dk/win-win-ways-cleantech-business24 July 2009Ris DTU National Laboratory for Sustainable Energyand theTechnical University of Denmark(of which Ris is now part). In 2012, companies in the Cleantech Cluster experienced growth as well as an increase in the launching of new products and services.cite webhttp://www.cphcleantech.com/home/publications/reports/ccc-monitor-2012Monitor 2012Copenhagen Cleantech201220 November 2013
article.heading: Cityscape
article.paragraph: File:Nyhavn copenhagen.jpgthumb200pxrightNyhavn, theseventeenth centurywaterfront, with its colourful buildingsThe city's appearance today is shaped by the key role it has played as a regional centre for centuries. Copenhagen has a multitude of districts, each with its distinctive character and representing its own period. Other distinctive features of Copenhagen include the abundance of water, its many parks, and thebike pathbicycle pathsthat line most streets.cite webhttp://www.visitdenmark.dk/da/koebenhavn/arkitektur/koebenhavns-forskellige-bydeleKøbenhavns forskellige bydeleVisit Denmark18 November 2013Danish
article.heading: Architecture
article.paragraph: See alsoArchitecture in CopenhagenList of buildings in and around CopenhagenFile:Amagertorv, Copenhagen.jpgthumb200pxAmagertorvsquare dates back to theMiddle AgesFile:restad, Copenhagen skyline.jpgthumbright200pxDeveloping skyline of therestaddistrict, located on the outskirts of CopenhagenThe oldest section of Copenhagen'sinner cityis often referred to asMiddelalderbyen(TheMiddle AgesMedievalCity).cite webhttp://www.guides.dk/Turforslag/Bytur-i-Koebenhavn.htmlKøbenhavn - byen ved vandet ...Guides.dkDanish20 November 2013However, the city's most distinctive district isFrederiksstaden, developed during the reign ofFrederick V of DenmarkFrederick V. It has theAmalienborgAmalienborg Palaceat its centre and is dominated by the dome ofFrederik's Church(or the Marble Church) and several elegant 18th-centuryRococomansions.cite webhttp://www.verdensarv.dk/english/candidates/frederiksstad-with-amalienborg/Frederiksstad with AmalienborgKultur Styrelsen20 November 2013The inner city of Copenhagen includesSlotsholmen, a little island on whichChristiansborg Palacestands andChristianshavnwith its canals.cite webhttp://www.visitcopenhagen.com/copenhagen/sightseeing/copenhagen-city-centreCopenhagen city centreVisit Copenhagen20 November 2013Around the historical city centre lies a band of congenial residential boroughs (Vesterbro, CopenhagenVesterbro,NrrebroInner Nrrebro,Indre sterbroInner sterbro) dating mainly from late 19th century. They were built outside the old ramparts when the city was finally allowed to expand beyond its fortifications.cite webhttp://www.noerrebrolokalhistorie.dk/historie.phpLidt Nørrebro-historieNørrebro Lokalhistoriske Forening og Arkiv21 November 2013Danish

Sometimes referred to as "the City of Spires", Copenhagen is known for its horizontal skyline, broken only by the spires and towers of its churches and castles. Most characteristic of all is theBaroquespire of theChurch of Our Saviour, CopenhagenChurch of Our Saviourwith its narrowing external spiral stairway that visitors can climb to the top.cite webhttp://www.denstoredanske.dk/Kunst_og_kultur/Arkitektur/Danske_kirker/Vor_Frelsers_KirkeVor Frelsers Kirke (København)''Den Store Danske''21 November 2013DanishOther important spires are those ofChristiansborg Palace, theCopenhagen City HallCity Halland the former Church of St. Nikolaj that now houses amodern artvenue. Not quite so high are theRenaissance architectureRenaissancespires ofRosenborg Castleand the "dragon spire" ofBrsenChristian IV's former stock exchange, so named because it resembles the intertwined tails of four dragons.cite bookKnud Kapper HansenTårne, spir og kupler: om Københavns og Frederiksbergs karakteristiske tårnlandskabhttps://books.google.com/books?id1995Tårngruppen

Recent years have seen a boom in modern architecture in Copenhagencite webhttp://www.baumeister.de/B1 Kopenhagen entdeckenBaumeister – Zeitschrift für Architektur2009Germanboth forArchitecture of DenmarkDanish architectureand for works by international architects. For a few hundred years, virtually no foreign architects had worked in Copenhagen, but since the turn of the millennium the city and its immediate surroundings have seen buildings and projects designed by top international architects. At the same time, a number of Danish architects have achieved success in Copenhagen and abroad. Buildings in Copenhagen have wonRoyal Institute of British ArchitectsRIBA European Awardsfour years in a row ("Sampension" in 2005,cite webhttp://www.e-architect.co.uk/awards/riba_awards_2005.htmRIBA European Awards 2005RIBA"Kilen" in 2006,cite webhttp://www.architecture.com/Awards/RIBAEuropeanAwards/2006/Kilen/KilenDenmark.aspxRIBA European Awards 2006RIBA"Tietgenkollegiet" in 2007 and theRoyal Danish PlayhouseRoyal Playhousein 2008.cite webhttp://www.architecture.com/Awards/RIBAEuropeanAwards/2008/RoyalPlayhouse.aspxRIBA European Awards 2009RIBA) The last three are all byLundgaard & TranbergLundgaard & Tranberg Architects.cite webhttp://www.ltarkitekter.dk/Lundgaard & Tranberg ArchitectsLtarkitekter.dk9 March 2013At the 2008World Architecture Festivalin Barcelona,Bjarke IngelsBjarke Ingels Groupwon an award for the World's Best Residential Building 2008 for a house in restad.cite webhttp://www.worldarchitecturefestival.com/news-detail.cfm?newsIdWorld's Best Residential Building 2008World Architecture FestivalIn 2008 British design magazineMonocle (2007 magazine)Monoclenamed Copenhagen theWorld's best design city 2008.Cite newshttp://www.independent.co.uk/travel/news-and-advice/copenhagen-probably-the-best-city-in-the-world-842782.htmlWorld's best design city 2008The IndependentUKEmilyDugan9 June 2008

The boom inurban planningurban developmentandmodern architecturehas brought some changes to the city's skyline. A political majority has decided to keep the historical centre free of high-rise buildings, but several areas will see or have already seen massive urban development.restadnow has seen most of the recent development. Located nearCopenhagen Airport, it currently boasts one of the largest malls in Scandinavia and a variety of office and residential buildings as well as theIT University of CopenhagenIT Universityand a high school.cite webhttp://www.orestad.dk/~/media/Orestad/pdf/Copenhagen-Growing_web.ashxCopenhagen growing''By&Havn''21 November 2013
article.heading: Parks, gardens and zoo
article.paragraph: MainParks and open spaces in CopenhagenFile:Rosenborg - park setting.jpgthumbleftRosenborg Castleand park in central CopenhagenCopenhagen is a green city with many parks, both large and small.Rosenborg Castle GardensKing's Garden(langdaKongens Have), the garden ofRosenborg Castle, is the oldest and most frequented of them all.cite webhttp://www.ses.dk/392755f0King's GardenSlots- og Ejeondomsstyrelsenhttps://web.archive.org/web/20080329224035/http://www.ses.dk/392755f029 March 2008It wasChristian IV of DenmarkChristian IVwho first developed its landscaping in 1606. Every year it sees more than 2.5 million visitorscite webhttp://www.aok.dk/byen-rundt/kongens-haveKongens HaveAOKElse Marie Brakchi15 November 2007and in the summer months it is packed with sunbathers, picnickers and ballplayers. It serves as asculpture gardenwith both a permanent display and temporary exhibits during the summer months.Also located in the city centre are theUniversity of Copenhagen Botanical GardenBotanical Gardensnoted for their large complex of 19th-century greenhouses donated byCarlsberg GroupCarlsbergfounderJ. C. Jacobsen.cite webhttp://www.carlsbergdanmark.dk/omos/Historie/IJacobsensfodspor/Kobenhavn/Pages/BotaniskHave.aspxBotanisk HaveCarlsbergFlledparkenatconvert58haonis the largest park in Copenhagen.cite webhttp://www.aok.dk/byen-rundt/faelledparkenFælledparkenAOKAf Kasper Olsen15 November 2007

File:General view - Copenhagen Zoo - DSC09119.JPGthumbrightThe old elephant house atCopenhagen Zoo, no longer in useIt is popular for sports fixtures and hosts several annual events including a free opera concert at the opening of the opera season, other open-air concerts,carnivaland Labour Day celebrations, and theCopenhagen Historic Grand Prix, a race forantique cars. A historicalgreen beltgreen spacein the northeastern part of the city isKastellet, CopenhagenKastellet, a well-preserved Renaissancecitadelthat now serves mainly as a park.cite webhttp://kastelletsvenner.dk/index.php?pageKastellets historieKastellets Venner & Historiske Sampling21 November 2013DanishAnother popular park is theFrederiksberg Gardens, a 32-hectareromanticismromanticlandscape gardenlandscape park. It houses a colony of tameGrey Herongrey heronsand otherwaterfowl.cite webhttp://www.slke.dk/kongelige-haver/frederiksberg-have-og-soendermarken/frederiksberg-have/Frederiksberg HaveSlotte & Kulture-Ejendomme21 November 2013DanishThe park offers views of the elephants and the elephant house designed by world-famous British architectNorman Foster (architect)Norman Fosterof the adjacentCopenhagen Zoo, the largest zoo in Denmark.cite webhttp://www.arcspace.com/features/norman-foster--partners/elephant-house/Elephant House: Norman Foster & Partnersarcspace-com21 November 2013Langelinie, a park and promenade along the innerresundcoast, is home to one of Copenhagen's most-visited tourist attractions, theThe Little Mermaid (statue)Little Mermaid statue.cite webhttp://www.visitcopenhagen.com/copenhagen/langelinie-gdk414235LangelinieVisit Copenhagen21 November 2013

In Copenhagen, manycemeterycemeteriesdouble as parks, though only for the more quiet activities such as sunbathing, reading and meditation.Assistens Cemetery (Copenhagen)Assistens Cemetery, the burial place ofHans Christian Andersen, is an important green space for the district ofNrrebroInner Nrrebroand a Copenhagen institution. The lesser knownVestre CemeteryVestre Kirkegaardis the largest cemetery in Denmark (convert54haon) and offers a maze of dense groves, open lawns, winding paths, hedges, overgrowntombs, monuments, tree-lined avenues, lakes and otherList of garden featuresgarden features.cite webhttp://www.kk.dk/da/brugbyen/brug-steder-i-byen/groenne-omraader/kirkegaardeKirkegårdeKøbenhavns KommuneDanish21 November 2013

It is official municipal policy in Copenhagen that by 2015 all citizens must be able to reach a park or beach on foot in less than 15 minutes.cite webhttp://www.dac.dk/da/dac-cities/baeredygtige-byer/alle-cases/groen-by/koebenhavn-lommeparker--groenne-aandehuller-i-byen/København: Lommeparker - Grønne Åndehuller i ByenDAC & Cities21 November 2013DanishIn line with this policy, several new parks, including the innovativeSuperkilenin the Nrrebro district, have been completed or are under development in areas lacking green spaces.cite webhttp://www.dezeen.com/2008/10/05/suk-project-by-big-architects/Superkilen by Bjarke Ingels GroupDezeen5 January 2009
article.heading: Landmarks by district
Indre By
article.paragraph: File:Christianshavns Kanal boats.jpgthumbleftChristianshavnCanalThe historic centre of the city,Indre Byor the Inner City, features many of Copenhagen's most popular monuments and attractions. The area known asFrederiksstaden, developed byFrederik V of DenmarkFrederik Vin the second half of the 18th century in theRococostyle, has the four mansions ofAmalienborg, the royal residence, and the wide-domedFrederik's ChurchMarble Churchat its centre.cite webhttp://www.denstoredanske.dk/Danmarks_geografi_og_historie/Danmarks_historie/K%C3%B8benhavns_historie/FrederiksstadenFrederiksstaden''Den Store Danske''27 November 2013DanishDirectly across the water from Amalienborg, the recently completedCopenhagen Operastands on the island ofHolmen, CopenhagenHolmen.cite webhttp://www.faktalink.dk/titelliste/openCharlotte Haase, Susanne NørgaardOperaenFaktalink27 November 2013DanishTo the south of Frederiksstaden, theNyhavncanal is lined with colourful houses from the 17th and 18th centuries, many now with lively restaurants and bars.cite webhttp://www.copenhagenet.dk/cph-map/cph-nyhavn.aspNyhavnCopenhagenet.dk27 November 2013The canal runs from the harbour front to the spacious square ofKongens Nytorvwhich was laid out byChristian Vin 1670. Important buildings includeCharlottenborg Palace, famous for its art exhibitions, theEmbassy of France, CopenhagenThott Palace(now the French embassy), theRoyal Danish Theatreand theHotel D'Angleterre, dated to 1755.cite webhttp://www.visitcopenhagen.com/copenhagen/kings-new-square-gdk428111King's New SquareVisit Copenhagen27 November 2013Other landmarks in Indre By include the parliament building ofChristiansborg, theCopenhagen City HallCity HallandRundetrn, originally an observatory. There are also several museums in the area includingThorvaldsen Museumdedicated to the 18th-century sculptorBertel Thorvaldsen.cite webhttp://travel.usnews.com/Copenhagen_Denmark/Neighborhoods/Copenhagen Neighborhoods and TownsU.S. News Travel27 November 2013Closed to traffic since 1964,Strget, the world's oldest and longest pedestrian street, runs theconvert3.2kmonfrom Rdhuspladsen to Kongens Nytorv. With its speciality shops, cafs, restaurants, andbuskers, it is always full of life and includes the old squares ofGammel TorvandAmagertorv, each with a fountain.cite webhttp://www.copenhagenet.dk/cph-map/CPH-Pedestrian.aspThe Pedestrian Street -'Strøget'Copenhagenet.dk1 December 2013Rosenborg Castleonster Voldgadewas built by Christian IV in 1606 as a summer residence in theRenaissance architectureRenaissancestyle. It houses the Danish crown jewels andDanish Crown Regaliacrown regalia, theThrone Chair of Denmarkcoronation throneand tapestries illustrating Christian V's victories in theScanian War.cite webhttp://www.visitcopenhagen.com/copenhagen/rosenborg-castle-gdk410582Rosenborg CastleVisit Copenhagen6 December 2013
article.heading: Christianshavn
article.paragraph: File:Halmtorvet seen from ksnehallen.jpgthumbHalmtorvetinVesterbro, CopenhagenVesterbroChristianshavnlies to the southeast ofIndre Byon the other side of the harbour. The area was developed byChristian IV of DenmarkChristian IVin the early 17th century. Impressed by the city ofAmsterdam, he employed Dutch architects to create canals within itsChristianshavns Voldrampartswhich are still well preserved today.The canals themselves, branching off the centralChristianshavns KanalChristianshavn Canaland lined with house boats and pleasure craft are one of the area's attractions. Another interesting feature isFreetown Christiania, a fairly large area which was initially occupied by squatters during student unrest in 1971. Today it still maintains a measure of autonomy. The inhabitants openly sell drugs on "Pusher Street" as well as their arts and crafts. Other buildings of interest in Christianshavn include theChurch of Our Saviour, CopenhagenChurch of Our Saviourwith its spiralling steeple and the magnificent RococoChristian's Church, CopenhagenChristian's Church. Once a warehouse, theNorth Atlantic Housenow displays culture from Iceland and Greenland and houses theNoma (restaurant)Nomarestaurant, known for its Nordic cuisine.cite webhttp://www.visitcopenhagen.com/copenhagen/maritime-christianshavn-holmenMaritime Christianshavn & HolmenVisit Copenhagen27 November 2013cite webhttp://www.aok.dk/byliv/guide-to-christianshavnGuide to ChristianshavnAOK27 November 2013
article.heading: Vesterbro
